pr_title: Separate the SDK into separate publishable artifacts

timeline.bodyText: I am not a gradle expert, by any means, but I think we might want to actually have this module have multiple source sets, so downloading it from maven central, or wherever, is a single artifact, rather than multiple artifacts, which is what having dependent modules will result in.
timeline.author: jkwatson
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,54 @@
+plugins {
+    id "java"
+    id "maven-publish"
+
+    id "me.champeau.gradle.jmh"
+    id "ru.vyarus.animalsniffer"
+}
+
+description = 'OpenTelemetry SDK'
+ext.moduleName = "io.opentelemetry.sdk"
+ext.propertiesDir = "build/generated/properties/io/opentelemetry/sdk"
+
+dependencies {
+    api project(':opentelemetry-api'),
+            project(':opentelemetry-sdk-common'),
+            project(':opentelemetry-sdk-correlation-context'),
+            project(':opentelemetry-sdk-metrics'),
+            project(':opentelemetry-sdk-tracing')

replies.bodyText:
That's just for "all" which is the new "sdk" right?
I'm ok with doing that if someone can explain/show how.
replies.author: kenfinnigan

replies.bodyText: Here's an example of this being done: https://github.com/newrelic/newrelic-telemetry-sdk-java/pull/214/files
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: and, yes, just for the 'all' artifact.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: I generally find multiple sources to have a higher chance of biting later (if both source files end up in the final app which is reasonably likely). Is there an advantage to the fat jar for an SDK? Don't feel that strongly one way or another but would lean towards letting Maven do it's thing, it's pretty good at it
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Can someone confirm whether or not I should make this change?
replies.author: kenfinnigan

replies.bodyText: I don't feel super strongly about it, so if someone cares a lot, we can have it as a follow-up issue/PR.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText:
I had to do that because the class is in the "tracing" module, which isn't a dependency of "common".
As it was for Javadoc purposes, I thought it would be ok.
Are there alternatives? I couldn't find an easy way to reference a class in another module without adding a bunch of things to the javadoc command line
replies.author: kenfinnigan

replies.bodyText: hmm. good point. I might get rid of the reference altogether to the concrete class, and just reference something like "Tracer or Meter Provider".
